div.head: St. Charles' Boarding and Day School
div.p: This institution, lately established, is directed by the Sisters of St. Charles Barrameo.
It is situated in a quiet and healthy part of the City near Helouan Railway Station, and is accessible by the Nasrieh and Old Cairo tram lines.
The course of studies comprises the English, German, and French languages, all branches of useful knowledge, needlework, music and painting.
Terms very moderate.
For further information apply to SISTER SUPERIOR, ST. CHARLES' SCHOOL, 11, Sharia-el-Kassed, Cairo.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newpaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, OCTOBER 31, 1904.

div.head: "PEACE WITH HONOUR."
div.p: Within the last day or so we have been on the very brink or war with Russia. Had such a dastardly outrage upon our fishing fleet been perpetrated in the good old days, admirals of the Nelson type would have sent the remnant of the Russian navy to the bottom long before it had reached the coast of Spain. Now-a-days, however, with the facilities for rapid communication furnished by telegraphs and telephones, such terrible crises can be happliy averted without bloodshed. Protests are launched, explanations interchanged, sovereigns throw their personal influence into the scale, and diplomacy is called into play, with the combined result of pouring oil on troubled waters and easing a tension which in earlier times must inevitably have led to hostilities. We should be sorry to think that the old spirit, which would not brook an insult to England on the part of a foreigner, has become softened by a higher state of culture, and that we would to-day clamly submit to see the honour of our nation outraged one whit more than our forefathers would have done. This feeling still lives, and our telegrams have shown that the entire nation is at one in demanding reparation for what was not only a blunder but a dsatradly crime. The general consensus of opinion, as evinced by the great London daily newspapers, show that the solution of this difficulty has been received with satisfaction. It is to be hoped, therefore, that the wrong will be fully recognised by the arbitrators and that the cuase of international comity will be served by the righteousness of their award.

div.head: AGRICULTURAL DEPARTMENT WANTED.
div.p: A short time ago a rumor was started to the effect that the Egyptian Government was about to form and Agricultural Department, but the report was found to have been merely based on the fact that an increased grant was to be made to the Khedivial Agricultural Society. It is much to be regretted that the Government should have failed to have boldly faced the pressing necessities of the situaution, in view of the very large amount of funds now placed at its disposal. We could have wished that agriculture ahould have received a larger share of administrative attention than heretofore, as for years past we have persistently advocated in these columns that expediency of giving effect to its claims. Afterall, husbandry in Egypt is an industry which in magnitude and importance immeasurably transcends all other. The expenditure, therefore, connected with the establishment of a department exclusively devoted to the fostering and development of its interests would be money profitably employed. "Agriculture" in its purely technical sense is restricted

to the cultivator of the fields, whereas in its loose popular sense it covers every kind of farming and includes, therefore, land development on its pastoral side, e.g., sheep, dairy and ostrich farming, poultry rearing, and horse breeding, as well as the raising of special crops. We trust there in no disrespect in suggesting that the heads of the Public works Department, though they be eminent authorities on irrigation, dam construction, and the soil of the Nile Valley, have not had occasion in a professional capacity to grow so much as a cabbage, and are therefore lacking that experience which alone can form a true foundation for the special knowledge required by an agriculturist. We must confess to our inability to fathom the reasons for such speculative daring being manifested by the Government in embarking on gigantic schemes for irrigation whilst the one and only purpose for which such schemes are undertaken is utterly neglected. Even in England, where, unfortunately, in our days, agriculture holds quite a secondary place, there is a full-pledged Borad uncontrolled by and Department save the Treasury, and capable of taking independent action. Why the should Egypt wait.

div.head: "HONOUR TO WHOM," ETC.
div.p: Considerable indignation is expressed by the public at the unwarrantable attack on the Alexandria Fire Brigade which appeared in Saturday's La Reforme in connection with Friday's fire at that newspaper's printing establishment. We can only surmise that our usually sober contemporary had lost its head in the excitement engendered by the regrettable conflagration. The Reforme not only makes an utterly gratuitous and uncalled-for attack on the Brigade, but indulges in distasteful personalities concerning its chief, Superintendent Lynn, which should never have appeared in its columns. We think that few, if any, of the spectators of the work done by the Fire Brigade in extinguishing the conflagration will begrudge giving it the credit which it is due. To have completely mastered the outbreak, when it had already assumed considerable proportions, within the space of half-an-hour, redounds to the credit of the Brigade and its chief. Our contemporary makes the astounding assertion that the Brigade arrived only 43 minutes after having received notice of the fire. This statement we can only characterise as baseless. We were ourselves witnesses of the arrival of the engines and the firemen, and cannot bear out our contemporary's assertion, which moreover is disproved entirely by the official recoreds kept by the Fire Brigade and the Municipality. It is to be regretted that La Reforme should have gone out of its way to cast a slur on the effciency of our Fire Brigade, which is generally recognised as being of a hogh order.

div.head: SUDEN EXPERIMENTAL PLANTATION SYNDICATE.
div.p: Mr. Leigh Hunt, the American millionaire, who is the moving spirit of the Sudan Experimental Plantation Syndicate, is expected to arrive at Cairo to-day from Europe. He will make a short stay in the Capital and will then proceed South to the site of his concession, near the river Atbara. A number of experienced men have been there organising the various departments of the syndicate's sphere of operations for the last three months, and a good deal of preliminary work of organisation has been already got through.

Mr. Werner Biet, the well-known South African millionaire, is one of the members of the syndicate, and he inntends probably coming to Egypt this season as he is grealty interested in the success of the syndicate.

div.head: NEW BANK IN EGYPT.
div.p: Mr. Paccelli, manager of the Bance di Roma, along with Com. Tittoni, a cousin of the Italian Minister for Foreign Affairs, and Mr. Benucci, recently arrived at Alexandria in order to consider the advisability of establishing a branch of the bank in egypt. We understand that the opinion formed by these gentlemen of the prospects of a branch here is favourable to its establishment, and there is every likelihood of the proposal being carried through.

div.head: IRRIGATION PUMPS.
div.p: Gwynne's (Limitied) have obtained an important contract for the supply of irrigation pumping machinery for the great syndicate,of which Mr. Leigh Hunt is the moving spirit, for cotton growing in the Sudan. This firm have over half a century's experience as hydraulic engineers, and have turned out centrifugal pumpimg machinery capable of discharging 363,636 cubic metres of 363 rivers as large as the Thames, or 72 rivers as large as the Nile.

Mr. A. L. Webb, of the Irrigation Department, when in Holland in 1897, on behalf of the Egyptian Government, gave and excellent report as to the working of Gwynne's machinery in that country. In his work on Egyptian Irrigation Sir William Willcocks remark:– "Indeed if it were not that the quality of English engines is so high and the Gwynne's pumps themselves nearly indestructible, pumping machinery would have succumbed to the Persian wheels." (See page 246 "Egyptian Irrigation, 1889"). Some of these machines have been at work for over fifty years.

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea Central position. Under English managemnt.

div.head: NORTH SEA OUTRAGE.
div.p: THE COMING ENQUIRY.
TSAR AND THE CRISIS.
London, October 29.

Mr. Balfour stated that the Russian naval authorities would ascertain which officers were responsible, and the same will not proceed to the Far East. An International Court of Enquiry, as provided for by the Hague Convention, and not a court of arbitration, will enquire into the facts. There will also be a special Board of Trade enquiry at Hull at which it is hoped Russia will be represented.

Mr. Balfour ridiculed Admiral Rodjestvensky's tale as a romance, which was really an attack on our national honour. It was only bare justice to say that the Tsar and the Russian Government had never underrated the crisis, nor failed to do what they could to diminish it. They had always shown an enlightened desire that truth and justice should prevail.

div.head: PRESS OPINIONS.
div.p: The Standard and Morning Post are dissatisfied, and consider that the settlement does not redound to the credit and dignity of Great Britain
The Standard is of the opinion that no guarantee has been given that the Baltic Fleet will be kept out of mischeif, since the Russians have not acknowledged their error.
The Morning Post says we should like to know more about the proportion of the Fleet, and the rank and number of offices detained at Vigo.
The Daily Telegraph states that it is a triumph for common-sense and humanity. Not a single point has been surrendered.
The Daily Chronicle says that the British people will be sincerely pleased at the solution.
The Daily News considers it as a mighty victory for the principles of conciliation and arbitration.
(Reuter.)
London, Octiber 30.
The whole Continental Press rejoices with reference to the international enquiry, which is greatly strengthening the cause of peace throughout the world.
Admiral Sir C. Bridge and Mr. Aspinall, K.C., have been appointed to report upon the damage and compensation in connection with the outrage to the trawlers.
The Home Fleet is concentrating at Portland.
(Reuter.)

The rest of the fleet will remain at Vigo, where the British cruiser Lancaster has arrived. (Reuter.)

Four Russian battleships and seven torpedo-boats have arrived.
(Havas.)

Four Russian destroyers have passed here travelling eastwards.
(Reuter.)

(Reuter.)
Vigo, October 30.
Admiral Rodjestvensky is remaining temporarily here. He has returned the courtesy visit paid him by the commander of the British cruiser Lancaster.
(Havas.)

The Japanese Minister here has protested against the coaling and provisioning facilities given to the Russian fleet at Vigo.
The Spanish Minister replied that other countries had given the same facilities. (R.)

div.head: FRIDAY'S FIRE.
div.p: The amount of damage caused by the fire which broke out in Penasson's printing office on Friday is estimated at L.E. 4,900.

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS
div.p: found in the Ghezireh district of Cairo and its neighbourhood during the night of the 3rd inst. will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: PUBLIC WORKS CONTRACT.
div.p: The construction of intakes of water on the Nagael, Achmoun, and Telwana canals in Menoufieh has been assigned to Mr. A. W. Murdoch.

div.head: SLAVE TRADE REPRESSION DEPT.
div.p: During the month of September the department granted manumission papers to four Sudanese female slaves, two in Cairo and two on the Red Sea littoral.

div.head: "AT HOME" IN MR. ALDERSON'S GARDEN.
div.p: To-morrow (Tuesday), at 4.30 p.m., Rev. Canon and Mrs. Ward are "at home" to the members of the congregation of St. Mark's Alxandria, and All Saints', Ramleh.

div.head: TOUKH STATION.
div.p: There is no truth in the remour published by the Cairo native papers, that the Railway Administration intends transferring Toukh station to another site. The station is simply to be enlarged.

div.head: ALL SAINTS' CHURCH, RAMLEH.
div.p: The services at this church on All Saints' Day (Tuesday), will be: 8.30 a.m., Ho;y Communion; 11 a.m., morning prayer; 6.30 p.m., evensong and sermon (preacher, Bishop Morley, D.D.)

div.head: ACCIDENT.
div.p: The right leg of Mohamed Effendi Safwat, mamour at the Alexandria Custom-house, was accidentally broken on Saturday afternoon by the fall of a log of wood from a passing cart. He was removed to the Deaconesses' Hospital for treatment.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL.
div.p: On the 27th inst. 6 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 4 were British and 2 German. The transit and passenger dues for the day amounted to 208,278.18 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 336 vessels amounted to 8,854,856.79 frs.

div.head: MYSTERIOUS MURDER.
div.p: On the night of the 26th inst. the headless body of an unknown man was found close to the bridge at Dahadous village, Mit Ghamr. The body was in a state of decomposition. The sous-chef of the Parquet and the mamour of the Markaz have arrived at the scene of the murder to hold an equiry.

div.head: CHARGES AGAINST POLICE OFFICER.
div.p: A council of disipline was help this mornin at the Gouvernorat for the trial of Mr. C. Camilleri officer at the Menshieh police-office, on the charge of having allowed a native prisoner in a state of intoxication to die without receiving attention, and not discovering the fact until a few hours after.

div.head: SANITARY DEPT.
div.p: The following are permitted to exercise their profession in Egypt: Wadih Sendawi, Const. Despotopoulos, Amin Kanaan Massif, Mahmoud Fauzi, Mustafa Sharawi, Mohamed Taher, M. Tewfik Sidki, Ahmed Fahmy el Reshid, Abd el Aziz el Aghizy, doctors; and Rachid Haddad and Mohamed Labib, Pharmacists.

div.head: THE KEDIVIAL YACHT
div.p: Mahroussa came out of dry-dock yesterday morning, after being inspected by the engineer, specially sent out from England for the purpose. The latter has made out his report on the repais needed by the yacht and sent it to the Ministry of Finance, for the necessary credit to be opened. The mahroussa is to be sent to England to be overhauled next summer.

div.head: SERIOUS AFFRAY AT ASSOUAN.
div.p: FIGHT AMONG BISHAREEN.
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
Assouan, Saturday.– A very serious fight occurred here a few days ago amongst the Bishareen Arabs at their camp outside the town, in the course of which some 20 men were badly injured.

There appears to have been a quarrel between two of the natives, which, from a personal matter, developed into a general scrimmage, bith parties gathering together their supporters, with the result that knives and stickes were freely used.

Had it not been for the prompt appearance of what we- for the want of a better (or worse) term- call the police force, composed of some hundreds of Bishareen, would have been engaged in a hand-to-hand encounter, but before much blood had been shed the police had put a stop to further strife.
About 20 men are now cooling their heads in prison, and a further 17 with broken pates and knife wounds are peacefully reposing in hospital.

div.head: ROYAL VISITORS.
div.p: Prince George of Hanover has left Gmunden on his way to Cairo, and he will stay in Egypt for about eleven months for the benefit of his health, and will probably be joined in February by the Duke and Duchess of Cumberland.

div.head: THE MAHARAJAH'S VISIT.
div.p: Lord Cromer called at Shepheard's Hotel yesterday afternoon and paid a visit to the Maharajah of Jhalawar. The Maharajah left Cairo this morning at 11 o'clock en route for Port Said and embarks there on the P. amd O. S.S. Egypt, which is due at Port Said to-morrow. The Maharajah is returning to India after a long tour in Europe.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: During the absence on leave of El Lewa St. G.C. Henry Pasha, C.B., Adjutant General, El Kaimakan Palmer Bey, Assitant Adjutant General, KHartoum, will take over the duties of Acting Adjutant General.
El Bimbashi H.E. Dumbell, 11th Sudanese, passed the preliminary Arabic examination help on the 1st August.
Leave of absence, on private affairs, has been granted to El Miralai Gorringe Bey, C.M.G., D.S.O., Moudir, sennar Province, and El Bimbashi Amery, Assistant Director of Intelligence.

Officers commanding Sudanese battalions are now permitted to enlist boys instead of men up to 25% of existing vacancies. The boys enlisted should show signs of being able to bear arms within three years.
Winter clothing will be taken into wear from Saturday next.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
div.p: Captain Mears, Commanding Army Service Corps, Alexandria, will join at Khartoum for duty on the 7th December next. He will be relieved at this station by Captsin Crawley, M.V.O., A.S.C., early next month. Captain Crawley recently arrived from England.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: No fresh localities have been reported infected with cattle plague sice the 29th inst.
Two fatal cases of plague have occurred among a lot of 30 head of cattle in Mex quarantine park, which arrived from Alexandretta by the S.S. Mariout on the 23rd inst.

div.head: BUBONIC PLAGUE.
div.p: A fresh case of plague was reported from Damietta on Saturday.

div.head: PLAGUE CREDIT.
div.p: According to the Mokattam, the Ministry of Finance has opened a new credit of L.E. 15,000 for the Sanitary Department to cover the cost of fighting the bubonic and cattle plagues.

div.head: NATIVE COURTS.
div.p: At the next meeting of Council of Ministers the following transfers will be approved:–

Mohamed Bey Fadly, Jdge at Beni Soeuf, to Zagazig; Tewfik Bey Amin, Judge at Zagazig, to Cairo; Tewfik haky Bey, Judge at Assiout, to Tantah; Wasif Bey Semekeh, Judge at Cairo, to Beni Souef, and Ibrahim Bey Wagieh, Judge at Beni Souef, to Zagazig.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Congo, which left Marseilles on the 27th inst. passed the Straits of Messins last Saturday at 5 p.m. and is due here to-morrow.
The S.S. City of Dundee left Malta on Saturday evening and is expected to arrive at this port with mails and passengers on Wednesday morning.

div.head: CHRYSANTHEMUM SHOWS.
div.p: KHEDIVIAL HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY.

The annual Chrysanthemum Show of the Kedivial Horticultural Society was held at Ghezireh on Saturday and Sunday. On Saturday, the Earl and Countess of Cromer, Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, and many of the leading members of the Kedivial Societies of Agriculture and Horticulture were present. The weather was fine and warm, rather too warm for many of the exhibits, which had begun to droop and wither by Sunday afternoon. The exhibtion was on the whole a success, though this year has been anything but a good one for chrysanthemums, and though H. H. Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel, who has been in former years one of the mostsucessful exhibitors on a large scale, was unable to compete owing to the sudden death about a fortnight ago of his chief gardener, whose professional skill was well known.
Mrs. Foaden and Ahmed Bey Khouloussi were by far the most successful exhibitors, winning no less than 13 first rpizes between them, besides numerous seconds. The following were the awards:–
Class 1. Group of at least 25 pots of Chrysanthemums.– 1st, Ahmed Bey Khouloussi; 2nd, Miss Florence Curtis.
Class 2. Group of at least 12 pots of Chrysanthemums.– 1st, Ahmed Bey Khouloussi; 2nd, Mrs. Foaden.
Class 3. Group of at least 6 pots of Chrysanthemums.– 1st, Ahmed Bey Khouloussi; 2nd, Mrs. Foaden.
Class 4. Group of at elast 3 pots of Chrysanthemums grown for decorative purposes rather than for large flowers.– 1st, Ahmed Bey Khouloussi.
Class 5. One specimen or standard Chrysanthemum plant.– 1st, Ahmed Bey Khouloussi.
Class 6. The best collection of at least 10 pot plants in flower other than Chrysanthemums.– 1st, Ahmed Bey Khouloussi.
Class 7. Collection of 48 blooms of Chrysanthemums.– 1st, Mrs. Foaden; 2nd, Ahmed Bey Khouloussi.
Class 8. Collection of 24 blooms of Chrysanthemums.– 1st, Mrs. Mackenzie.
Class 9. Collection of 12 blooms.– 1st, Mrs. Mackenzie; 2nd Mrs. Asser.
Class 10. Collection of 6 blooms.– 1st, Mrs. Foaden; 2nd, Mrs. Asser.
Class 11. Zinnias (one box).– 1st, Miss Florence Curtis; 2nd, Ahmed Bey Khouloussi.
Class 12. Cannas (one box).– 1st, Ahmed Bey Khouloussi.
Class 13. Dahlias (one box).– 1st, Mr. giliberti; 2nd, Ahmed Bey Khouloussi.
Class 14. Collection of flowers not previously specified (2 boxes at least).– 1st, Mr. Giliberti.
Class 15 Ditto, Ditto (1box at least).– 1st, Mr. Giliberti.
Special prize for Roses.– Dr. Keatinge.
The first prize in classes 16, 17, 18, and 19 for baskets and vases of chrysanthemums and ither flowers fell in each case to Mrs. Foaden.
In classes 20 and 21, for nurserymen, no 1st prize was awarded, but both 2nd prizes were won by Muhamed Said El Kebir.
The special medal of the Royal Horticultural Society of England fell to the Tanzim Department, Ghizeh Nursery. Special objets d'art for pot and cut chrysanthemums were won by Mr. H. L. Cutis.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY.
div.p: The Alexandria Horticultural Society's seveth annual Chrysanthemum Show, held at San Stefano on Saturday and yesterday, is the largest exhibition of the kind that has ever been held here. It was so much larger than last year's that there was no room for the cut flowers in the large ball-room of the casino, and they and some of the pot plants had to be accommodated in the reading-room. Great credit is due to Lady Blomfield, Mr. Rolo, and Mme C. Debban, who, although living in the heart of Alexandria has never seen two such beautiful boxes of chrysanthemums as thise sent by Mr. Rolo, and amongst his collection was the best chrysanthemum in the show. The feature of the large groups were the masses of white bloom. All the groups showed much better taste than in the earlier exhibitions. The flowers were arranged by masses of colours, as they are in Europe, and there was not that mixture of colour which was far from artistic in the earlier shows. The Municipality showed some very fine blooms, but theywere not for competition. The show was well attended on both days. The following is the prize-list:–

div.head: THE STATE OF HELOUAN.
div.p: PUBLIC INDIGNATION.

There was a meeting yesterday morning of the Helouan Local Commission, but, as is usually the case, there were not sufficient members present to forma quoram, for only three of the commission turned up.

There was an informal dicussion on the subject of the railway time-table, and it was agreed that the Delta Railway Company should be approached with a view to having a better time-table when it takes over the line.

We hear that the inhabitants of Helouan are si indignant at the little practical use which the Local Commission is the the town, that it is proposed to organise an indignation meeting, at whihe the many grievances which the inhabitants suffer from, owing to the badness of the roads and the impracticable railway time-table, which is most inconvenient for travellers between Cairo and Helouan, will be aired.

div.head: POST OFFICE BUDGET.
div.p: Saba Pasha, the Postmaster-General, is at presnt in Cairo, where he is conferring with the Ministry of Finance on the next year's budget of the Post Office Administration. The budget is to be drawn up on a liberal scale, and many reforms and improvements will consequently be introduced in this administration.

div.head: BISHOP MORLEY'S VISIT TO TANTAH.
div.p: Bishop Morley leaves Alexandria this afternoon for Tantah, where he will be the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Suter. His lordship holds a service at 7.30 p.m. in the church-room, and on Tuesday morning reads morning prayer and celebrates the Holy Communion, preaching both Monday evening and at the morning service on the following day.
The Bishop returns to Alexandria about midday on Tuesday.

div.head: RAMLEH RAILWAY.
div.p: NEW CABLE LAID.

The Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company completed the laying down of the spare electric cable between Bulkeley and Karmous on Saturday night, and last night the necessary tests for trying the insulation resistance were made. This morning, at 5 o'clock, the new cable was taken into service. It may now be reasonably hoped that no further breakdowns will take place in the company's service.

div.head: CHILDREN'S SAVINGS BANKS.
div.p: A SPLENDID INNOVATION.

An excellent scheme for promoting thrift among the children of this country has been elaborated by the Postmaster-General and will come into force on January 1. On and after that date any children, whose parents are desirous of encouraging thrifty habits in their offspring, will be furnished, on application at the post-offices throughout Egypt, with printed cards on which spaces will be allotted for ten five-millieme stamps. As soon as the child has filled up such a card with stamps to the value of P.T. 5, he will be able to present it to be deposited in the Post Office Savings Bank.
In order to extend the scope of of this beneficent measure all schoolmasters will be authorised to give such cards to any of the pupils under their charge.
The scheme is very praiseworthy and it will be interesting to observe how far it will be successful in Egypt.

div.head: CAIRO BRITISH RIFLE CLUB.
div.p: HIGH SCORING.

The shooting season 1904-1905 has commenced brilliantly at Tourah Range. At practice on the 22nd inst. the scoring was the highest on record for a first shoot down the range, Mr. Wolff finishing with the magnificent total of 101 out of a possible of 105, made up as follows;–
200 yds. = 84 + 500 yds. = 35 + 600 yds. 32 = total 101, although unfortunate enough to get a magpie for his last shot at 600.
Mr. Blake also shows excellent form, his last four scores reaching the respectable average of 94, over the three ranges.

div.head: Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
div.p: River Transport of Goods Between Alexandria & Cairo
Three Sailings a-Week.
Agents at Alexandria:
Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage, Ramleh.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in the finest part of Ramleh, close to Halte Laurans (Station after S. Stefano). Magnificent sea view. Prommade on shore. Sea Bath. Restaurant. Buffet. Splendid Garden. Electric Light. Moderate charges. Special terms.
Mrs. LUIGI STEINSCHNEIDER, Proprietor.
Telegraph Address: "Beuarivage," Telephone No. 185.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir R. Wingate Pasha, Sirdar and Governor-General of the Sudan, left Cairo for Khartoum on Saturday evening.
Ibrahim Pasha Fuad had returned to Cairo.
The Belgian Consul-General was received in audience by the Khedive on Satureday.

Brig.-Gen Graves, commanding at Freetown, Sierra Leone, who (as stated in Saturday's "Army and Navy" notes) is named as one of those likely to get promotion to major general at an early date, is first cousin to Lady Blomfield.
Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of Alexandria City Police, returned yesterday from Cairo.
Commander Gedge, R.N., and Socrates Spiro Bey, who have been to Cairo on duty connected with the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, returned to Alexandria yesterday.
Among the Alexandrians staying at Shepheard's Hotel are Mr. and Mrs. S. Salvago, Saba Pasha, Postmaster-General of the Mixed Courts, and Macauley Bey.
Colonel Battey, Colonel Templeton, Colonel and Mrs. Colville, and Captain and Mrs. Kennedy are also staying at Shepheard's.

Mme von Deppe and lady companion, Messrs. Jack and M. de Zonneborn, from Hamburg, arrived at Port Said yesterday by the North German Lloyd's S.S. Grosser Kurfurst and proceeded at once to Al Hayat, Helouan, where they intend making a prolonged stay.

The Winter Hotel, Helouan, opened yesterday. Amongst its first visitors are the Hon. Mrs. Davey and children, Mrs. R.D. Zalichi, Miss M. Zalichi, Mr. M.D. Zalichi, Pinkipo; Mr. Victor Paleologo, Mme Bonte, Miss Bonte, Miss Schrader, Berlin; Countess K. de Komar, Countess A. de Konar, Mlle M. de Rosanska and suite, Poland, who have taken rooms for the whole of the season. The hotel has been much improved and fitted up with electirc light.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demi)

Le marche des valeurs a debute tres ferme ce matin. Quelque tenips apres l'ouerture, les cours ont bausse d'une facon notable et, bien que vers la cloture quelques valeurs aient subi une legere reaction, la cote reste cependant plus elevee que samedi.
L'Agricole debute a 10 21/32, atteint 10 13/16 et cloture a 10 11/16 en excellente demande.
La Banque Nationale debute a 23 et atteint 23 1/8, prix auquel elle cloture offerte.
Durant toute la mtinee, la Delta Light a ete demandee a 15 11/32 et la Daira a 21 ½.
La Salt & Soda debute a 26/9, atteint 27/3 et cloture vendeurs a 27.
Les Privilegiees Tramways debutent a 141, atteignent 144 et cloturent a 142 ½.

div.head: COMPAGNIE UNIVERSELLE DU CANAL MARITIME DE SUEZ
div.p: AVIS
VENTE DE MACHINES, PIECES DE RECHANGE ET FERRAILLE

La Compagioe Universelle du Canal Maritime de Suez met en vente des machines et pieces de rechange diverses dont elle n'a plus l'emploi ainsi que de la feraille provenant de la repatation de ses appareils, le tout actuellement despose dans ses Ateliers et Magasins a Port-Said et divise en 2 lots, savoir:
PREMIER LOT
Machines-outils, machines a vapeur, dynamos, treuils simples et doubles et appareils divers.
SECOND LOT
Environ 550 tonnes de ferraille composee de godets, pieces de rechange de dragues, bidons et bascules hors d'usage, rognures, riblons, vieilles toles, vieilles cornicres et fers divers usages.
Chaque lot fers l'objet d'une adjudication separee.

La vente aura lieu par soumission sous pli cachete, en 2 lots, dans les Bureaux de la Cie (Section des Ateliers, Materiel et Magasins) a Port-Said, le 14 Novembre 1904, a 10 heures du matin pour le premier lot et a 10 h. ½ pour le second.
On peut prendre connaissance, des maintenant, du Cahier des Charges et des Conditions de la vente:
Au caire, a l'Agence Superieure de la Compagnie;
A Ismailia, dans les Bureaux de M. l'Ingenieur en Chef;
A Port-Said, dans les Bureaux de la Section des Ateliers, Materiel et Magasins;
A Port-Tewfik, dans les Bureaux de la 3me Section.
L'Ingenieur en Chef de la Compagnie p.I.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS

Dans l'interet de l'hygiene publique et vu que dernierement 8 cas de rage parmi des chiens et un cas de rage sur un cheval se sons produius, Messieurs les proprietaires de rage sont pries de vouloir bien, au cas ou des symptoms suspects se produiraient chez leurs animaux en aviser immediatement le veterinaire municipal (Telephone No. 841).
Alexandrie, le 26 Octobre 1904.
L'Administrateur,
(Signe) W.P. CHATAWAY.
AVIS
La Municipalite met en adjudication la fourniture de M 12,000 de pierre pour dallage de Chaussee.
Le cautionnement est fixe a L.E. 480.
Le cahier des charges est depose au Bureau de la Voirie ou il peut etre consulte par les interesses tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours feries exceptes.
Les offres devront etre adressees sous pli cachete a Monsieur l"administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 6 decembre prochain.
Elles pourront egalement etre desposees en séance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour la fourniture de pierre pour dallage de Chaussee."

Le cautionnement ou le recu d'une banque, d'apres les condtions du cahier des charges, devra etre remis au Secretaire Financier avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 6 decembre prochain a midi.
Alexandrie, le 24 Octobre 1904.
L'Adiministrateur
(signe) W.P. CHATAWAY.
AVIS

Le Jeudi 10 Novembre 1904 de 10 h. a.m. 1 h. p.m. la Municipalite procedera a la vente aux encheres publiques pres des cimetieres Europeens sis a la Porte-Rosette, d'une quantite des pierres extraites des terrains des Fortifications par lots de 40 a 100 m6.
Les acheteurs devront deposer le 10% au moment de la vente et effe tuer le paiement du prix integral a la Caisse Municipale, le lendemain du jour de l'Adjudication.
Is auront a supporter les droits de carriered au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pie res schetees dans un delai de cinq jours, sous peiue de folls enchere pour compte de l'Adjudicataire.
L'Administrateur,
(signe) W.P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 25 octobre 1904.
